div.p:
Every one of
the letters which you so very
kindly wrote to us reached
us yesterday - Thank you
I cannot express how much
I feel obliged by your writing
all this in your situation
- However dreadful the de-
tails there is a sort of satisfac
tion in knowing the truth
& being relieved from suspense

- do you say the best we
can now hope is that this
noble creature may not sur
vive the loss of all that dis-
tinguished him among men
& that he may without more
suffering breathe his last -

- You surely cannot doubt
that we should think you
did right in sending the
young ones to Castle Forbes
- nothing could be better
- God bless Lady G - You have
a great comfort even in these
terrible circumstances in

feeling sure that wherever
your daughters & sons are
they are in all that depends
on their own conduct safe -
and must do you credit

Honora seemed to enjoy
her journey & the open carriage
- fine weather and change
of scene more even than you
could possibly have expected

- Her mind is admirably
calm - & more easily amused
than my own - Anna is
as you well know all kind
ness - and she has such delight
ful soft manners ha

Honora had such a headache
yesterday (the only one she has
had since we left Black Castle)
that I was glad we had not
received an answer to a note
I wrote Em. to say we wd. go there
yesterday - we have heard
from her to day - a very kind
note -. In an hours time we
are going - Honora's head pretty
well - as soon as I see how
things are at Clifton I will write
to you again - I have read your

letter to Aunt C - and will deli
ver it as I think her mind
is strong enough to bear the
truth and itm ust come
sooner or later - The shock might
be much worse if it came all
at once -

I did not receive from Mr.
Little the Bond - so I shall say
nothing of business & hope no-
thing will be said to me - If
the subject is touched upon I shall
say that Lovell & Sneyd had
ordered a bond to be drawn
but that it was not ready -

We shall stay till Thursday
I think - We have desired
Anna to forward any Irish
letters to us - as we live upon
your letters - My dear Fanny
wrote to me from Castle Forbes
so we know every thing about
you all as if we were with
you - I hope my dear mother
you continue to think I we
did right in com-
ing to England - If you wished
for us back again say but the
word and we will come at
any time - Thank God you will
tell me the truth -
This morning I read a most kind

letter from Lady Lansdowne
begging us to come to her as
soon as possible - I shall not
answer till we have seen my
aunts - I think it would be
dreadful to go into company
at present - and could not answer
any purpose for Honora - nor
could it be even proper - There-
fore I wish to put off the visit -
I will write As soon as I get to Clifton
& hear what my aunts say - I will
write to Lady L- and to Dumont
- I will tell Lady L my brother
is exceedingly ill - that we do
not wish &c - & I will write to
D- to ask if he can now read the
Ms. I will send it to him & if I can see him in Novr.
or if he stays at Bowood suppose
in Sepr.? Anna asks us to stay
here a fortnight & promises she
will let no company in - that
she will say at once W. has a
fever & that is sufficient answer

- Lady C Fitzgerald has been
exceedingly kind - She has been
here twice - has this moment
shewn me a letter from Lady G
saying she never pitied a creatures
so much in her life as she does
Fanny & you - that F is the picture
of pale grief - She speaks with great
fondness & admiration of P. & F- -& says they are
not the slightest trouble - to E's state
she says is hopeless but no danger of death.

- I wrote to your ex brother & have had
a most touchingly kind letter from
him - Dr. Baillie is very ill & I have
fears that this will prevent our
scheme of being with Joanna Baillie
- I shall write to her from Clifton -
- I have had a kind letter from Mr. Hope
wishing to see us -

I beg you will write one line & not
more dear mother to tell me whe-
ther you approve of what I propose
doing - I assure you I command me
ind & am as calm as possible -
But your approbation is necessary
to me -

Crampton promised to write to
Post Office Shrewsbury but I suppose
he had nothing to say - We have not
heard from him - I wonder he
has not gone down to you

Give my most affectionate love &
admiration to Lovell -
